From copilot:

Katie Johnson filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump, alleging that he raped her when she was 13 years old. The case was dismissed almost a decade ago. The lawsuit claimed that the assaults happened at parties hosted by Jeffrey Epstein. You can find more details here.

Katie Johnson’s deposition was part of her lawsuit against Donald Trump, which was filed in federal court in Riverside, California, in April 2016. The lawsuit named Trump and Jeffrey Epstein as defendants and claimed that they held Johnson as a “sex slave” and assaulted her when she was 13 years old. However, the case was dismissed shortly after it was filed. You can find more details here.

Katie Johnson’s lawsuit against Donald Trump was dismissed because the judge ruled that the complaint didn’t raise valid claims under federal law. Additionally, there were legal hurdles, such as the statute of limitations on many of the claims, including sexual misconduct, assault, and battery. The case was dismissed in May 2016, and subsequent versions of the lawsuit were also withdrawn or dismissed.

Katie Johnson’s lawsuit against Donald Trump was withdrawn because she reportedly received threats and was too afraid to continue with the case. Her attorney, Lisa Bloom, mentioned that Johnson was too frightened to appear at a scheduled news conference. The case was ultimately dropped without further explanation.

posts.title: Protesters in Turkey rally 'for justice' after mayor's arrest - BBC News
top_comments:
#Tear Gas and Turmoil as Turkey Rises for Justice

The streets of Istanbul have been lit up not by celebration but by the fierce glow of protest as thousands rally for justice following the arrest of the city’s mayor, Ekrem Imamoglu. For four nights running, crowds have surged across Turkey’s major cities, marking the country’s largest wave of demonstrations in over a decade. What began with a few scattered gatherings has now grown into a roar of resistance.

Imamoglu, long seen as a serious rival to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was taken into custody on Wednesday, just days before his party was expected to confirm him as their presidential candidate for 2028. Accused of corruption and aiding terrorist groups, charges he flatly denies, his arrest has shaken the political landscape and drawn thousands into the streets demanding his release.

On Saturday, he appeared in court, his supporters chanting "rights, law, justice" outside as tear gas swirled in the cold night air. Riot police stood shoulder to shoulder, firing round after round to break up the crowds, but still they came. Mothers holding their children, students in masks, pensioners waving flags, all united by a shared belief that something fundamental is slipping away.

"I'm here for liberty," one young woman told the BBC, her face hidden behind a mask. "Turkish people cannot accept this. This is against our behaviour and culture." Her words echoed the mood across Istanbul, where the government has banned public gatherings in a bid to quell the unrest. But the ban only seems to have poured fuel on the fire.

In Izmir and Ankara, the story was much the same. Water cannons, arrests, more tear gas. On Friday alone, 343 people were reportedly detained. Still, the crowds held their ground, shouting not in anger but in defiance, determined to be heard. There is an unmistakable feeling that this is no longer just about one man, but about the future of democracy itself in Turkey.

Imamoglu’s bid for the presidency now hangs in the balance. Just a day before his arrest, Istanbul University stripped him of his degree, citing irregularities. If upheld, this would disqualify him from running, as Turkish law requires a university qualification for presidential candidates. The timing has raised eyebrows across the political spectrum.

President Erdogan, who has ruled the country for over two decades, cannot stand again in 2028 unless the constitution is changed. Critics argue that the arrests of Imamoglu and more than a hundred others, including journalists and business figures, are an attempt to clear the political field before the next election. The government, for its part, insists the judiciary is acting independently and has hit out at those suggesting otherwise.

Whether or not that claim holds weight, what is clear is that a growing number of Turkish citizens feel they are being silenced. The sheer courage of those risking arrest to march night after night speaks volumes. These protests are no longer just about one politician behind bars. They are about the soul of a nation, and the kind of future its people are willing to fight for.

I was in the protests in İzmir yesterday and today, and the police have been illegally throwing pepper spray bombs in the air, using concentrated pepper gas, pepper gas releasing plastic bullets, pressurized water and agent orange with riot control vehicles, and shooting people with plastic bullets, and doing all that without announcing they were going to use excessive force to the public, which is also illegal.

posts.title: Canada can win trade war: Foreign affairs minister Mélanie Joly
top_comments: Winning is diversifying, can’t win outright but can look to other markets and can come out stronger

We can, and we will

It will involve careful counter tariffs, an expansion into new markets, cleaning up our internal trade barriers and massive investment in infrastructure that both facilitates getting our goods to foreign markets and the cross country movement of the same

But, none of that will matter without huge investment into our military and our military industrial manufacturing complex (which could use a lot of the metals and other resources the USA apparently doesn’t want) so Trump knows we will be just as ugly to conquer as Ukraine has been
There are no winners in trade wars, regardless of anything politicians or their pet economists may say.

No we can't.. It's an uneven battle to begin with just financially, we can't go tariff-for-tariff because we don't have the cash to sail through that. The best we can do is find better, more reliable trade partners, and just wait on the U.S to finish itself off.

(Article is pretty much nonsense either way, she offers no statement on how Canada can win, just a sentiment that hopefully they decide it's bad for everyone and end it)
Must be smoking some good shit up there

posts.title: Protesters in Turkey rally 'for justice' after mayor's arrest - BBC News
top_comments:
#Tear Gas and Turmoil as Turkey Rises for Justice

The streets of Istanbul have been lit up not by celebration but by the fierce glow of protest as thousands rally for justice following the arrest of the city’s mayor, Ekrem Imamoglu. For four nights running, crowds have surged across Turkey’s major cities, marking the country’s largest wave of demonstrations in over a decade. What began with a few scattered gatherings has now grown into a roar of resistance.

Imamoglu, long seen as a serious rival to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was taken into custody on Wednesday, just days before his party was expected to confirm him as their presidential candidate for 2028. Accused of corruption and aiding terrorist groups, charges he flatly denies, his arrest has shaken the political landscape and drawn thousands into the streets demanding his release.

On Saturday, he appeared in court, his supporters chanting "rights, law, justice" outside as tear gas swirled in the cold night air. Riot police stood shoulder to shoulder, firing round after round to break up the crowds, but still they came. Mothers holding their children, students in masks, pensioners waving flags, all united by a shared belief that something fundamental is slipping away.

"I'm here for liberty," one young woman told the BBC, her face hidden behind a mask. "Turkish people cannot accept this. This is against our behaviour and culture." Her words echoed the mood across Istanbul, where the government has banned public gatherings in a bid to quell the unrest. But the ban only seems to have poured fuel on the fire.

In Izmir and Ankara, the story was much the same. Water cannons, arrests, more tear gas. On Friday alone, 343 people were reportedly detained. Still, the crowds held their ground, shouting not in anger but in defiance, determined to be heard. There is an unmistakable feeling that this is no longer just about one man, but about the future of democracy itself in Turkey.

Imamoglu’s bid for the presidency now hangs in the balance. Just a day before his arrest, Istanbul University stripped him of his degree, citing irregularities. If upheld, this would disqualify him from running, as Turkish law requires a university qualification for presidential candidates. The timing has raised eyebrows across the political spectrum.

President Erdogan, who has ruled the country for over two decades, cannot stand again in 2028 unless the constitution is changed. Critics argue that the arrests of Imamoglu and more than a hundred others, including journalists and business figures, are an attempt to clear the political field before the next election. The government, for its part, insists the judiciary is acting independently and has hit out at those suggesting otherwise.

Whether or not that claim holds weight, what is clear is that a growing number of Turkish citizens feel they are being silenced. The sheer courage of those risking arrest to march night after night speaks volumes. These protests are no longer just about one politician behind bars. They are about the soul of a nation, and the kind of future its people are willing to fight for.

I was in the protests in İzmir yesterday and today, and the police have been illegally throwing pepper spray bombs in the air, using concentrated pepper gas, pepper gas releasing plastic bullets, pressurized water and agent orange with riot control vehicles, and shooting people with plastic bullets, and doing all that without announcing they were going to use excessive force to the public, which is also illegal.
